ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to identify and translate Maya hieroglyphs.
An introduction to deciphering Mayan glyphs, and an overview of where the field of decipherment is today/how it got there.
I learned so much about reading and interpreting Maya hieroglyphs and Classic Maya texts. This was an incredible course in teaching this for students of all different academic backgrounds.

I learned how to read hieroglyphics! I wasn't sure if we would just analyze translations or learn history, but we genuinely learned how to read which was amazing. I am not a scholar on the subject, but I can definitely figure out what a passage is talking about and when it was written.
I developed the ability to read and understand glyphic texts as well as a working knowledge of Maya civilization.
I learned how to read Classic Mayan Hieroglyphics. In doing so, we also overviewed linguistic anthropology, the history of Mayan decipherment, and Classic Mayan history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I learned a lot in this course, it was extremely thorough.

I really enjoyed 417 overall. There were a couple class periods, though, when we switched from more of a lecture-based format to a more seminar-style discussion  I thought that was particularly engaging, and looking back I wonder if it couldn't be integrated into the course more prominently.
The reading section of this course is strong and engaging. The lectures and assessments are also formatted very well.

The presentation of course material is well thought out. The beginning part of the course on linguistics felt a little mundane at times (when I wanted to dive right into hieroglyphics), but the material in the first few weeks ends up being very useful in analyzing the Mayan language. The progression of the course through the textbook is clear and naturally builds on itself. This maximized my understanding of the material and allowed me to feel comfortable with the language by the end of the course. The only weakness that I can think of was that homework assignments could be unpredictable and some took much longer than others.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if the student wanted to learn how to read Maya hieroglyphs this is an excellent class.
I would definitely recommend this course if you are interested in learning about Classic Maya texts and culture.
Yes. This course is excellent. If a student is interested in studying Maya civilization, it is essential to take it.
Yes. Take this course. You will not regret it.
